newsitem.title: USA: Maxim, U.S. version of British men's magazine, debuts.
newsitem.headline: Maxim, U.S. version of British men's magazine, debuts.

text.p: A new men's magazine is hitting the newsstands Tuesday, April 1. If the idea of "cheesecake," comes to mind, be advised that the only serious cheesecake photograph in Maxim is likely to be in a recipe.

But while there might not be a preponderance of cleavage photos, Maxim, the U.S. version of the two-year-old British magazine of the same name, is all about women -- and what men should do to meet them, woo them and keep them warm, cosy and ready for love.
Maxim is seeking out 22- to 49-year-old male readers -- those too hip for GQ and Esquire and too staid for Details. Call it something like a "Cosmopolitan" for guys.
"Men want very simple information -- they want it to give them an edge. Men don't like to ask for directions, but want to know what the other guys don't," said Maxim's editor-in-chief Clare McHugh.

Clare McHugh, that's right, she's a she. This fact, she said, will give Maxim an edge. Coming from a women's magazine background, she said she sees the importance of bringing service journalism to a magazine for men.
Men want to know about sports, travel, food and gadgets, she said, but Maxim hopes to offer something that its more straight-laced competitors don't, and that's a healthy dose of humour.
Features such as "Are you a Mac guy or a PC guy," "The Seinfeld Girls," and "How To: Get along with her pop" slide over the edge into satire.
Maxim flaunts that it has a woman editor with a letter to readers and her picture gracing the first issue.
"Women can get away with" the tone of many of Maxim's articles, McHugh said, which includes the liberal use of puns in titles and picture captions.
"It allows an article like 'babe management,'" she said, which is a decidedly satirical look at "investing in the woman of your dreams."
More serious articles on cars, sports and an account of the death of an ice climber balance out the mix.
Unlike Penhouse or Playboy, Maxim will not run political or highly controversial articles, McHugh said.

Then there's lingerie. Following McHugh's claim that men want to know but don't want to ask, an article entitled "The gift that keeps on giving" is a buyer's guide to women's lingerie, including suggestions for styles to match a woman's personality.
Food also will play a large part in Maxim's editorial direction, McHugh said from the New York-based magazine's office.

In the debut issue, a feature walks the reader through preparations for a romantic meal, including salad, tenderloin of beef, steamed asparagus, and the never-fail recipe for love -- chocolated-covered strawberries. Another article outlines affordable, available wines.
Under the current format, Maxim will never be confused with a porn magazine, McHugh said, and in fact was reformatted from its British relation.

U.S. Maxim might have similar articles as the British magazine but they are executed differently. Maxim on this side of the Atlantic is less "laddish," which McHugh defined as "the glorification of male boorishness."

Maxim is joining a growing field of magazines catering to men. Separate from so-called adult magazines, which might have photographs of nude women, Maxim is part of a growing segment of service-oriented men's magazines.

New additions to the genre include Personal Best, a spin-off from Conde Nast's GQ, which is scheduled for Spring 1998; Times Mirror's Verge, which is due this spring; and the independently published Icon, currently in distribution.
Maxim, published by Britain's Dennis Publishing Inc., currently has a press run of 350,000 copies. It will come out monthly and has a newsstand price of $2.99, or $3.50 Canadian.
